subject: probability
title: Probability Density Function
subtitle: The core of continuous random variables
contentHtml:
A probability density function (PDF) is a fundamental concept in continuous random variables. It describes the likelihood of a value occurring within a given interval.

The PDF, denoted by f(x), satisfies two essential properties:

  • It's non-negative: f(x) ≥ 0 for all x.
  • The area under the curve is equal to 1: ∫[−∞, ∞] f(x) dx = 1.
intuition: Think of the PDF as a probability mass function, but instead of being discrete, it's continuous. This allows us to model real-world phenomena with greater precision.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, PDFs are used in Bayesian inference and Gaussian mixture models.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse the PDF with the cumulative distribution function (CDF), which describes the probability of a value occurring up to a certain point.

title: Probability Density Function
contentHtml:
The probability density function (PDF) of a continuous random variable X is a fundamental concept in probability theory.

Given a random variable X with PDF f(x), the probability that X falls within a specific interval [a, b] is given by the integral ∫abf(x) dx.
name: PDF Properties" },
whyMatters: The PDF provides a way to describe the likelihood of different outcomes for continuous random variables, which is essential in many real-world applications, including machine learning and artificial intelligence.
intuition: Think of the PDF as a 'density map' that shows how likely it is for X to take on different values. The integral of the PDF over an interval gives you the probability that X falls within that interval.
